from flask import Blueprint
from werkzeug.exceptions import NotFound


# Blueprint to contain the view that returns 404 if API calls are made to
# the web app instead of the api flask application
api_404_bp = Blueprint('api_404', __name__)


@api_404_bp.route('/1/submit_listens', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
@api_404_bp.route('/1/user/<user_name>/listens', methods=['GET'])
@api_404_bp.route('/2.0/', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
@api_404_bp.route('/api/auth/', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def webapp_api_call(user_name=None):
"""
This route is used to raise 404s when api calls are made to the webapp
instead of the api.
"""
raise NotFound("Incorrect address used in call to API, please use api.listenbrainz.org instead.")

@@ Code changes:
change_summary:
The GIT DIFF shows that a new file has been added. This file imports the Blueprint module from flask and the NotFound exception from werkzeug.exceptions. It then defines a new Blueprint named 'api_404'. 

Four routes are added to this blueprint: '/1/submit_listens', '/1/user/<user_name>/listens', '/2.0/', and '/api/auth/'. These routes are associated with the function 'webapp_api_call', which raises a NotFound exception with a custom error message when accessed. 

This suggests that these routes are intended to handle API calls that are incorrectly made to the web application instead of the API. The custom error message advises the user to use 'api.listenbrainz.org' for API calls.

The code change in the GIT DIFF replaces an existing line of code. The replaced line of code now passes "nodesAddresses" as an argument to the "NewWebsocketGossipNode" function instead of "phonebooks[nodeIdx]". This suggests that the gossip node is now being created with a list of node addresses instead of a specific phonebook.

The code change adds a new condition to the validateOptions function. This condition checks if the "options" property of the "keeper" object is null. If it is, the function will return an error stating "no KeeperOptions provided". This indicates that the function now checks for the existence of KeeperOptions before proceeding with the rest of the validation.

The code changes in this GIT DIFF modify the behavior of the "remove" command in a command-line interface. 

Originally, the command required exactly one argument (the alias to be removed), as indicated by the line "Args:  cobra.ExactArgs(1)". The updated code changes this to allow between zero and one arguments, as shown by the line "Args:  cobra.RangeArgs(0, 1)".

The command usage has also been updated to reflect this change, with the argument "ALIAS" now being optional (indicated by the square brackets) in the line "Use:   "remove [ALIAS]"".

The method of removing the alias has also been changed. Previously, the alias was removed directly from the arguments provided to the command. Now, the alias is first retrieved from the configuration using the "GetAddressOrAlias" method, and then removed. This change also introduces error handling for the case where the alias retrieval fails.

The code change in the GIT DIFF removes a comment and a line of code that was running the "stream.FullClose()" function in a separate goroutine. Instead, it now runs the "stream.FullClose()" function in the same goroutine and ignores the returned error by assigning it to the blank identifier "_". This change suggests that the developer no longer considers it necessary to run the "stream.FullClose()" function in a separate goroutine to avoid deadlocks when cheques are sent simultaneously in both directions.

The code change in the GIT DIFF removes an if-else condition that checks if the ReturnType.Body is not null. Previously, if the ReturnType.Body was not null, it would append "response.body unless response.nil?" to the builder. If the ReturnType.Body was null, it would append "nil" to the builder. Now, regardless of the ReturnType.Body value, it will always append "response.body unless response.nil?" to the builder. This simplifies the code and assumes that the response body will always be accessed, regardless of whether ReturnType.Body is null or not.

The code has added a new function named "GetBitAlignment" to the "SwiftLanguageRuntime" class. This function takes a "CompilerType" object as a parameter and returns an optional size. Inside the function, it checks if the type information is available for the given type. If it is, it returns the alignment of the type. If the type information is not available, it returns an empty optional.

The code change in the GIT DIFF adds a new line to determine if the row format is aligned using the method "isSqlmxAlignedRowFormat()". The condition for encoding needed for serialization is then updated to only check if encoding is needed when the row format is not aligned. This suggests that the encoding process is not required for aligned row formats.

The code change in the GIT DIFF replaces an existing line of code. The replaced line of code now uses the "fatal" function to output an error message and terminate the program if the remote name is an absolute path. The original line of code used the "fprintf" function to output the error message but did not terminate the program. This change indicates that the presence of an absolute path in the remote name is now considered a fatal error.

The code change adds a new error handling block. If an error occurs when converting a hexadecimal string to a private key, the function will now return an error message stating "failed to HexString private key". This improves the error handling of the function by providing more specific feedback when a certain operation fails.

The function signature of "newResponse" has been changed to return two values instead of one: an error and a v1.VolumeStats object. Previously, it only returned a v1.VolumeStats object. 

In the function body, the error handling has been modified. If there is an error during the unmarshalling of the JSON, the function now returns the error along with the metrics object. If there is no error, it returns nil for the error and the metrics object. This change improves error handling by providing more information about potential issues during the unmarshalling process.

The code changes in this GIT DIFF include the addition of a new boolean variable "blockWatcherInitialized" set to false. If the coupon is valid, it updates the total price displayed on the page, hides any error messages related to the coupon, hides the total link and the coupon field, and sets the value of the "purchase_stripe_coupon_id" field to the coupon code. This cache is created with a capacity of 4096 entries, a timeout of 86400 seconds (one day), and a callback function to destroy cache entries. Finally, the main function is run with the first element of the annotatedOutputLabels array. This change seems to add more robustness and error checking to the code.

+
+// TestOOMContainer verifies that an OOM container returns an error
+func TestOOMContainer(t *testing.T) {
+	agent := RunAgent(t, nil)
+	defer agent.Cleanup()
+
+	testTask, err := agent.StartTask(t, "oom-windows")
+	require.NoError(t, err, "Expected to start invalid-image task")
+	err = testTask.WaitRunning(waitTaskStateChangeDuration)
+	assert.NoError(t, err, "Expect task to be running")
+	err = testTask.WaitStopped(waitTaskStateChangeDuration)
+	assert.NoError(t, err, "Expect task to be stopped")
+	assert.NotEqual(t, 0, testTask.Containers[0].ExitCode, "container should fail with memory error")
+}
change_summary: The GIT DIFF shows the addition of a new function named "TestOOMContainer". This function is a test case that verifies if a container that runs out of memory (OOM) returns an error. The test starts an agent and a task named "oom-windows", waits for the task to run and then stop, and finally asserts that the exit code of the container is not zero, indicating that the container should fail due to a memory error.

The code changes add a new field called "FailureDomain" to the AWSMachineSpec struct. This field is a pointer to a string and is optional. The comments indicate that this field is the unique identifier for the failure domain that the machine should be attached to, as defined in the Cluster API. The ID is equivalent to an AWS Availability Zone. If multiple subnets match the availability zone, the first one returned is picked. 

Additionally, a comment has been added to the "AvailabilityZone" field indicating that it is now deprecated and users should switch to using the new "FailureDomainID" field.

@@ Code changes:
change_summary:
The code changes in the GIT DIFF modify the way the Boltdir directory is found. Previously, the code was looking for a directory with the exact name "BOLTDIR_NAME". The new code is more flexible and allows for variations in the case of the Boltdir name (e.g., "BoltDir", "boltdir", etc.). 

The new code also sorts the directories to ensure consistent selection between runs. It always chooses the lexicographically "less" Boltdir name rather than the first name returned by the filesystem. 

If a directory matching the Boltdir name is found, it is used to create a new 'embedded' instance. If no such directories are found, the code continues to the next conditions as before.

The GIT DIFF shows that a new field "transportSpec" of type "*compiledTransportSpec" has been added to the "Kit" struct. This field represents the TransportSpec currently being used, which may or may not be set. 

Additionally, a new method "withTransportSpec" has been added to the "Kit" struct. This method takes a "*compiledTransportSpec" as an argument and returns a shallow copy of the "Kit" object with the "transportSpec" field set to the provided argument. This method allows for the modification of the "transportSpec" field in a new copy of the "Kit" object, without affecting the original "Kit" object.

The code changes include the addition of two lines that apply filters to the variables $text and $button_link. These filters, named 'neve_translate_single_string', are likely used to translate the text and button link into different languages. This suggests that the code is being updated to support internationalization or localization.

The `ServiceName` property has been changed from mutable (with a getter and setter) to immutable (with only a getter). The constructor for `SpanContext` has been updated to include a `serviceName` parameter, and the `ServiceName` property is now set in the constructor. A comment questioning the mutability of `ServiceName` has also been removed. This indicates a design decision to make `ServiceName` immutable and to set its value at the time of object creation.

This suggests that the code is now capable of storing information about fields, specifically their names and array lengths, in the C# generator.

The code change in the GIT DIFF modifies the value of the constant "DefaultVaultKubernetesAuthMountPath". Originally, it was set to "kubernetes", but it has been changed to "/v1/auth/kubernetes/login". This suggests a change in the default mount path location for Kubernetes ServiceAccount authentication.

If it matches, it returns the existing eventLogInstance or creates a new one if it doesn't exist. The GIT DIFF shows the addition of a new file in the "kubernetes" package. This file contains a single function named "CheckPodsRunning". This function takes two parameters: a list of pods and an expected number of pods. The function checks if the number of pods is less than the expected number of pods, and if so, it returns false. It also iterates over the list of pods and checks if any of the pods are not in the "Running" state. If any pod is not running, it returns false. If all checks pass, it returns true. This function is used to verify if the expected number of pods are running.

The class has a constructor and one method named "isMatch". The "isMatch" method takes two parameters: a payload and a rule, both of which are strings. This field, when set to true, enables the agent to poll the container instance's metadata endpoint for an EC2 spot instance termination notice. If such a notice is received, the agent will set the instance's state to DRAINING, which will gracefully shut down all running tasks on the instance. If the instance is not a spot instance, the poller will still run but will never receive a termination notice. By default, this field is set to false.

The method checks if _pkt is not None and its length is greater than or equal to 3. If this condition is true, it returns the result of getting the value of the third byte of _pkt from the dictionary _mip6_mhtype2cls, with a default value of cls. If the condition is false, it simply returns cls. This method seems to be used for dispatching based on the type of the packet.

change_summary:
The code changes in the GIT DIFF indicate a modification in the way OpenIDConnectPolicy is being fetched from the settings. Previously, the code was iterating over all items in the settings and using a regular expression to match and find the policies that end with 'OpenIDConnectPolicy'. 

In the updated code, it directly fetches the 'multiauth.policies' from the settings, splits them by space, and then iterates over these policies. For each policy, it gets the corresponding 'multiauth.policy.{policy}.use' from the settings and checks if it ends with 'OpenIDConnectPolicy'. If it does, it appends it to the openid_policies list. 

This change simplifies the code and potentially improves performance by reducing the number of iterations and eliminating the use of regular expressions.

The code change represented by the GIT DIFF replaces multiple import statements with a wildcard import statement. This change simplifies the import statements but could potentially import unnecessary classes.

# Get a random French SIREN number. See more here https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syst%C3%A8me_d%27identification_du_r%C3%A9pertoire_des_entreprises
def french_siren_number
base = (1..8).map { rand(10) }.join
base + luhn_algorithm(base).to_s
end

def french_siret_number
location = rand(100).to_s.rjust(4, '0')
org_no = french_siren_number + location
org_no + luhn_algorithm(org_no).to_s
end


@@ Code changes:
change_summary: The GIT DIFF shows that two new methods have been added to the Faker module. The first method, `french_siren_number`, generates a random French SIREN number. The second method, `french_siret_number`, generates a random French SIRET number. Both methods use the `luhn_algorithm` to generate the last digit of the number, ensuring that the generated number is valid according to the Luhn algorithm.

The code change represented by the GIT DIFF adds a null check for the "kickoutListRes" object before attempting to deserialize it. This is likely done to prevent a potential null pointer exception that could occur if "kickoutListRes" is null. The original code did not have this null check and would attempt to deserialize "kickoutListRes" regardless of whether it was null or not.

The code changes in the GIT DIFF modify the access modifiers of the class ParquetIO and its method file(). The class ParquetIO is changed from package-private (default) to public, and the method file() is also changed from package-private (default) to public. This means that both the class and the method can now be accessed from outside the package.

The code change in the GIT DIFF replaces the existing comparison of the 'expected' and 'actual' variables. Instead of directly comparing the two variables, the code now uses the 'DifferenceFinder.DiffIgnoringTimeStampsAndGUIDs' method to find differences between 'expected' and 'actual', ignoring any differences in generated GUIDs or timestamps. If no differences are found (i.e., the 'diff' variable is null or empty), the function returns. This change allows for a more nuanced comparison of the 'expected' and 'actual' variables, ignoring irrelevant differences.

The code changes in the GIT DIFF modify the condition for continuing the loop and the value assigned to the balance in the ChainSpecAllocation object. Originally, the loop would continue if the account's BuiltIn value was not null and the Balance was zero. Now, the loop continues if the account's BuiltIn value is not null and the Balance is null. 

Additionally, when creating a new ChainSpecAllocation object, the balance is now assigned the value of account.Value.Balance if it is not null, otherwise it is assigned UInt256.Zero. Previously, it was directly assigned the value of account.Value.Balance.

The code changes involve the removal of five lines and the addition of one line. The removed lines include a navigation command to "dashboard.html" and two event listeners for "viewshow" and "viewhide" events, which respectively add and remove the "noHomeButtonHeader" class to/from the ".skinHeader" element. 

The added line changes the navigation command to redirect the user to "index.html" instead of "dashboard.html". This suggests a change in the flow of the application, where the user is now redirected to the main index page instead of the dashboard after the startup process is complete.

The code added a new constant named "defaultPipedStatTTL" with a value of "2 * time.Minute". This suggests that a new time-to-live (TTL) setting has been introduced for piped stats, which is set to 2 minutes by default.

The GIT DIFF for this code shows no significant changes. The closing bracket of the class170 interface was removed and then added back in. This could be a formatting change or a mistake that was corrected.

The code change adds a new field "Config" of type json.RawMessage to the "createProducer" struct. This suggests that the "createProducer" struct now has the ability to store configuration data in raw JSON format.

The code change adds a new private field `_arrayPool` to the `EthashCache` class. This field is an instance of `ArrayPool<uint[]>` and is initialized with a call to `ArrayPool<uint[]>.Create(1024 * 1024 * 4, 50)`. This suggests that the `EthashCache` class now uses an array pool to manage its memory usage, specifically for arrays of unsigned integers.

change_summary: The code added a new method called "remove_blank_target". This method is designed to remove the target attribute from a link if it is set to "_blank". change_summary: The code change represented by the GIT DIFF removes a block of code that was previously used to handle characters that take multiple code points. The removed code used to encode the text to UTF-32 and calculate the ord manually for 32 bit characters. This was necessary in Python 2 but not in Python 3. The removed code also handled UnicodeEncodeError exceptions. Now, the code simply assigns None to the variable 'c' if a TypeError is encountered. This simplifies the error handling process.

The code change in the GIT DIFF modifies a conditional statement. The original condition checks if the component should not be forcefully updated and if the component should not be updated based on the "shouldComponentUpdate" method. The new condition maintains the original checks but adds an additional condition. It now also checks if the original version of the new virtual node is the same as the original version of the old virtual node and if the component is not processing an exception. If any of these conditions are met, the component's properties and state are updated.

The code changes in the GIT DIFF modify the method signature and the associated comment for the "getRootCategories" method in the "CategoryManagerInterface" interface. # frozen_string_literal: true

require 'bolt/error'
require 'bolt/config/transport'

module Bolt
class Config
class Sudoable < Transport
private def validate
run_as_cmd = config['run-as-command']
if run_as_cmd && (!run_as_cmd.is_a?(Array) || run_as_cmd.any? { |n| !n.is_a?(String) })
raise Bolt::ValidationError,
"run-as-command must be an Array of Strings, received #{run_as_cmd.class} #{run_as_cmd.inspect}"
end
end
end
end
end

@@ Code changes:
change_summary: The GIT DIFF shows the addition of a new file. The file includes a new class named 'Sudoable' which is a subclass of 'Transport' within the 'Config' class of the 'Bolt' module. The 'Sudoable' class has a private method 'validate' that checks if the 'run-as-command' configuration is an array of strings. If the 'run-as-command' configuration is not an array of strings, it raises a 'Bolt::ValidationError'.

class MoveClientAdminRole < ActiveRecord::Migration
def change
role = Role.find_or_create_by(name: 'client_admin')

User.client_admin_emails.each do |email_address|
user = User.find_by_email_address(email_address) or next
user.add_role(role)
user.save!
end
end
end

@@ Code changes:
change_summary:
The GIT DIFF shows the addition of a new class called "MoveClientAdminRole" which inherits from ActiveRecord::Migration. This class has a method "change" which is used to alter the database schema. 

In the "change" method, a role named 'client_admin' is either found or created. Then, for each email address in the 'client_admin_emails' of the User model, the user associated with that email address is found. If a user is found, the 'client_admin' role is added to that user and the user is saved. If no user is found, the loop moves to the next email address. 

This change indicates that a migration is being performed to add the 'client_admin' role to certain users in the database.

The code changes represented by the GIT DIFF replace a line of code that was using a callback-based connection to MongoDB with a promise-based connection. The new lines of code create a new MongoClient instance and then use the connect() method, which returns a promise. This change suggests a shift from callback-based asynchronous handling to promise-based asynchronous handling.

The code change in the GIT DIFF modifies the exception handling block. Originally, the code was catching a specific exception type, "SmilesParseException". The updated code now catches all types of exceptions, indicated by the ellipsis (...). This change broadens the scope of error handling in the program.

The variables include m_TimeSinceLastPositionCheck, m_DistanceSinceLastPositionCheck, m_ShadowStepExemption, m_KnockBackExemption, m_PortExemption, m_SenseExemption, m_AssistExemption, and m_CheatDetectMoved. The code change in the GIT DIFF replaces three lines of code with a single line. The code change in the GIT DIFF corrects a typo in a key of a dictionary. The original key was "commmmmand" and it has been corrected to "command". This change is likely to fix a bug where the 'gotoAnything' command was not being recognized due to the misspelled key.

The code change adds new lines to calculate the length of a segment in meters. It first retrieves the coordinates for the start and end nodes of the segment, identified by NodeIDs 'u' and 'v'. Then, it uses the haversine formula to calculate the distance between these two points, which represents the length of the segment.

Args:
capacity: Number of lines for the log.

raise cmdexc.CommandError("Please choose log capacity above 0.")

The function takes an integer argument 'capacity' which represents the number of lines for the log. If the 'capacity' is less than 0, the function raises a CommandError. Otherwise, it sets the 'ram_handler' of the 'log' to a new 'RAMHandler' with the specified 'capacity' and changes the log capacity to the specified 'capacity'.

The GIT DIFF shows that a new file has been added to the codebase. This file is part of the "auth" package and it defines an "Authenticator" type, which is a function that takes a username and password as input and returns a boolean and an error. 

A function called "NewAuthenticator" is also defined, which returns an instance of the "Authenticator" type. The current implementation of this function returns a function that checks if the username is "bad" and returns false if it is, and true otherwise. 

The code also includes a "TODO" comment, suggesting that the current implementation of the "NewAuthenticator" function is temporary and needs to be replaced with a more robust authentication mechanism in the future.

The GIT DIFF shows that a new function named `loggerVectorFindIf` has been added to the code. This function takes in a `LoggerVector` and a predicate function `LoggerPredFuc` as parameters. It then iterates over the `LoggerVector` and applies the predicate function to each element. If the predicate function returns a non-zero value for an element, the function returns the index of that element. If no such element is found, the function returns `SIZE_MAX`. This function essentially provides a way to search for an element in the `LoggerVector` based on a certain condition defined by the predicate function.

The code change adds a new struct called "Pleasings" with three fields: "Revision", "Location", and "PrintOnly". This struct is associated with the command "pleasings" and is described as initializing the pleasings repo. The "Revision" field is a string that represents the revision to pin the pleasings repo to, which can be a branch, commit, tag, or other git reference. The "Location" field is a string that represents the location of the build file to write the subrepo rule to, with a default value of "BUILD". The "PrintOnly" field is a boolean that, when true, prints the rule to standard out instead of writing it to a file.

The code changes in the GIT DIFF add a new condition to check if the filesystem is already frozen (EBUSY) in addition to the existing checks for operation not supported (EOPNOTSUPP) and operation not permitted (EPERM). If the filesystem is already frozen, a debug message is logged stating "Filesystem already frozen, falling back to syncfs". This change provides additional error handling for the scenario where the filesystem is already frozen.

The code change in the GIT DIFF modifies an existing condition in an if-statement. The original condition checked if the operating system version is greater than or equal to WINDOWS_VERSION_10_1511. The updated condition adds an additional check to ensure that the "inject_x64" option is not enabled. This means that the code block within the if-statement will only be executed if the operating system version is WINDOWS_VERSION_10_1511 or later and the "inject_x64" option is disabled.

+##
+# Module to help generate icon helpers for SVG images
+module Blacklight::IconHelperBehavior
+  ##
+  # Returns the raw SVG (String) for a Blacklight Icon located in

+  # @return [String]

+    Rails.cache.fetch([:blacklight_icons, icon_name, options]) do

+      content_tag(:span, icon.svg.html_safe, icon.options)
+    end    
+  end
+end

##
# Module to help generate icon helpers for SVG images
module Blacklight::IconHelperBehavior
##
# Returns the raw SVG (String) for a Blacklight Icon located in
# app/assets/images/blacklight/*.svg. Caches them so we don't have to look up
# the svg everytime.
# @param [String, Symbol] icon_name
# @return [String]
def blacklight_icon(icon_name, options = {})
Rails.cache.fetch([:blacklight_icons, icon_name, options]) do
icon = Blacklight::Icon.new(icon_name, options)
content_tag(:span, icon.svg.html_safe, icon.options)
end
end
end

change_summary: The GIT DIFF shows the addition of a new module named "Blacklight::IconHelperBehavior". This module includes a method named "blacklight_icon" which takes an icon name and options as parameters. The method fetches the SVG icon from the Rails cache if it exists, otherwise, it creates a new Blacklight::Icon instance and stores the SVG in the cache. The SVG is then wrapped in a span tag and returned. This change suggests that the codebase is implementing a caching mechanism for SVG icons to improve performance.

require 'travis/build/appliances/base'

module Travis
module Build
module Appliances
class DeprecateXcode64 < Base
def apply
if config[:osx_image] == 'xcode6.4'
sh.echo "Running builds with Xcode 6.4 in Travis CI is deprecated and will be removed in January 2019.", ansi: :yellow
sh.echo "If Xcode 6.4 is critical to your builds, please contact our support team at support@travis-ci.com to discuss options.", ansi: :yellow
end
end
end
end
end
end

change_summary: The GIT DIFF shows the addition of a new file that defines a new class, DeprecateXcode64, under the Travis::Build::Appliances module. This class inherits from the Base class and contains a single method, apply. The apply method checks if the osx_image configuration is set to 'xcode6.4'. If it is, it outputs a deprecation warning message indicating that running builds with Xcode 6.4 in Travis CI is deprecated and will be removed in January 2019. It also provides a contact for the support team for users for whom Xcode 6.4 is critical.

This change allows the code to selectively enable or disable tracing for different services.

The function checks if the option 'showSelectedFiles' is true, and if so, it sets this option to false and then back to true after a delay of 4 milliseconds. This effectively triggers the re-render.

change_summary: The code change represented by the GIT DIFF adds a new rule to a dictionary. The rule, identified by the key 'R1705', is described as 'Superfluous return before else'. The description explains that if an "if" block contains a return statement, the else block becomes unnecessary and its contents can be placed outside of the block. This suggests that the code is part of a linter or code quality checker, and this new rule is being added to check for unnecessary else blocks following return statements in if blocks.

The code changes represented by the GIT DIFF removed three lines of code. The removed lines were responsible for checking if the timer queue processor scope is active and incrementing a counter in the metrics client based on the timer task type and the active status. This suggests that the code no longer requires to track these metrics or the functionality has been moved elsewhere.

The code change represented by the GIT DIFF removes an empty line of code. This change does not affect the functionality of the code. It is likely a stylistic or formatting change to improve readability.

The code changes in the GIT DIFF modify the condition for returning the recovery id (recId) in a transaction. Previously, the code checked if the chainId was empty and returned the recId added to either REPLAY_UNPROTECTED_V_BASE or REPLAY_PROTECTED_V_BASE multiplied by twice the chainId. 

The new code first checks if the transactionType is not null and not equal to TransactionType.FRONTIER. If this condition is met, it returns the recId as is, indicating that this is an EIP-2718 typed transaction. If this condition is not met, it then checks the chainId as before. This change adds support for EIP-2718 typed transactions.

The code added a new conditional statement to check if the nodes map contains a key with the node's ID. If it does not, it calls the uploadExecutableNode method with the node and a new instance of Props as arguments. This suggests that the code is now ensuring that a node is uploaded before attempting to update it.

The replaced line of code now sets the endpoint URL to use HTTPS protocol instead of the original line of code that set the endpoint URL to use HTTP protocol. Additionally, a comment has been added indicating that both HTTP and HTTPS should be tested in the future.

The code change in the GIT DIFF modifies the declaration of the `_sampleRates` dictionary. The `static` keyword has been removed, which means that `_sampleRates` is no longer a static member of the class. Instead, it is now an instance member, meaning each instance of the class will have its own copy of `_sampleRates`.

The code change adds a new line that declares and initializes a static final array of Flags named SYNCFLAGS. The array contains four elements: Flag.SEEN, Flag.FLAGGED, Flag.ANSWERED, and Flag.FORWARDED. This suggests that these flags are used for synchronization purposes in the MessagingController class.

The code added a new method named "is_segwit". This method checks if the derivation starts with "m/49'/". This suggests that the code is checking if the derivation path is following the SegWit (Segregated Witness) standard.

The code change in the GIT DIFF adds a conditional statement to check if the public key derived from the private key matches the account. If it does, it prints the public and private keys as before. If it doesn't, it prints the public and private keys along with a message indicating that the private key is invalid. This change adds an extra layer of validation to the code.

The code change represented by the GIT DIFF removes a conditional statement that checks if the user domain is not equal to the constant USER_DOMAIN. If the condition was met, the code would create a top-level domain. This indicates that the code will now always create a top-level domain for user authentication, regardless of the user domain.

The code changes involve modifications to the way network and subnet parameters are handled. The previous code used string formatting to create the network and subnet paths. The new code uses the functions `param.GetRegionalResourcePath` and `param.GetGlobalResourcePath` to create these paths, which likely provides more robust and error-proof path creation.

Additionally, a new condition has been added to handle cases where a subnet is set but a network is not. In such cases, the network is now explicitly set to an empty string to avoid falling back to a default value. This change suggests that the code is now more considerate of different network configurations and is designed to handle a wider range of scenarios.

The code change in the GIT DIFF modifies the error handling for binding the wl_display to EGL. Previously, if the binding failed, it would log an informational message and return false. Now, it first checks if the bind_wayland_display_wl extension is supported. If it is, it attempts to bind the wl_display to EGL and logs an error message if it fails. If the extension is not supported, it logs an informational message stating that the extension is not supported.

The code change in the GIT DIFF modifies an import statement. Originally, the code was importing the "flatbuffers" module from a local file "./flatbuffers". The updated code now imports the "flatbuffers" module from the "flatbuffers" package. This suggests that the "flatbuffers" module is now being sourced from a package rather than a local file.

The code change represented by the GIT DIFF adds a new comment line. The comment indicates a future task or improvement that needs to be made in the code, specifically, the image needs to be rotated depending on the output rotation. This does not change any functionality of the code but serves as a reminder or note for future development.

The code changes include the addition of a block of code that checks if a connection has already been established with the MongoDB client. If a connection exists, it checks if the client is still connected. If it is, an error is thrown indicating that the client is already connected. If the client is not connected, it is considered a reconnect and the old state is cleared out. The topology is set to undefined, the options are reset to an empty object, the database cache is reset to a new Map, and the sessions are reset to a new Set. This block of code is added to handle reconnection scenarios more gracefully.

# Custom reporting for performance/sysstat messages
# Will not print unless we are at {LOG_LEVELS} 'debug' or higher.
# @param args[Array<String>] Strings to be reported
def perf_output *args
return unless is_debug?
strings = strip_colors_from args
string = strings.join
optionally_color MAGENTA, string, false
end


@@ Code changes:

It will only print if the log level is set to 'debug' or higher. The code change in this GIT DIFF modifies a log message. Originally, the message was "config center URL is missing, skip to load configuration from config center". Now, the message has been simplified to "config center URL is not configured". This change likely reflects a desire to make the log message more concise and straightforward.

The function signature for "RenewBeforeExpiryDuration" has been modified to include a new parameter "defaultRenewBeforeExpiryDuration". The default value for "renewBefore" has been changed from "cmapi.DefaultRenewBefore" to the new parameter "defaultRenewBeforeExpiryDuration". This allows the function to be more flexible as the default renew before expiry duration can now be passed in as an argument. 

Additionally, the condition to check if "renewBefore" is greater than "actualDuration" has been changed to check if "renewBefore" is greater than or equal to "actualDuration". This means that if "renewBefore" is exactly equal to "actualDuration", the "renewBefore" value will be set to a third of the "actualDuration". This change ensures that the "renewBefore" value is always less than the "actualDuration".

change_summary:
The code changes involve a restructuring of the conditions related to the 'predictor' and 'init_score' variables in the Dataset class. The previous code block was removed and replaced with a new block. 

In the new code, the check for 'predictor' being an instance of '_InnerPredictor' is moved up. If 'predictor' is an instance of '_InnerPredictor' and '_predictor' is None and 'init_score' is not None, a warning is issued that the 'init_score' will be overridden by the prediction of 'init_model'. 

If 'predictor' is not an instance of '_InnerPredictor' but 'init_score' is not None, 'init_score' is set. This is a change from the previous code where 'init_score' was set regardless of the 'predictor' type, and a warning was issued if 'predictor' was not None. 

The changes seem to be aimed at handling the 'init_score' and 'predictor' variables more efficiently and accurately.

The code change adds a new condition at the beginning of the "startAutoWalk" function. If the creature is a player and the player is in a "no move" state, the function will send a "cancel walk" command to the player and then return, preventing the player from auto-walking.

The hook takes two parameters: an array of actions that can be undone, and an optional source string that identifies the source of the action. If the hook returns false, the action of changing the undo stack is cancelled.

The code change adds a new line to retrieve the invisibility status of a player in the game. It declares a new boolean variable "isInvisible" and assigns it the value returned by the "isInvisible()" method of the player object.

The code change in the GIT DIFF modifies the way the test case checks if a property is indexed. Previously, it directly compared the 'indexed' property of the 'actual' and 'expected' objects. Now, it first checks if the property name is the primary key of the original object. If it is, the 'indexed' property of the 'actual' object is compared to either the 'indexed' property of the 'expected' object or the primary key status. This change ensures that the primary key is always indexed.

code_change:
@@ -3287,6 +3287,15 @@ NABoolean TSJRule::topMatch (RelExpr * expr,
       ((updateExpr->getOperatorType() == REL_UNARY_DELETE) && updateExpr->isMtsStatement()))
     return FALSE;
 
+  // It is not semantically correct to convert a MERGE having a 
+  // "NOT MATCHED" action to a TSJ, since the former has right 
+  // join semantics. (If we converted here to a TSJ, a non-matching
+  // row would not be returned by the outer child scan node, so
+  // the inner child merge node would never see it and hence the
+  // "NOT MATCHED" logic would not be activiated.)
+  if (updateExpr->isMerge() && updateExpr->insertValues())
+    return FALSE;
+
   return TRUE;
 }
change_summary: The code change adds a new condition to the function "topMatch". This condition checks if the update expression is a merge and if it has insert values. If both conditions are true, the function returns FALSE. This is to prevent the conversion of a MERGE with a "NOT MATCHED" action to a TSJ (Table Spool Join), as it is not semantically correct due to the right join semantics of the MERGE. The added lines also include comments explaining this logic.

change_summary: The GIT DIFF shows that seven lines of code were added to the AnchorHead class. These lines introduce a new parameter, "loss_normalizer_momentum", which is a float. The parameter is used for the Exponential Moving Average (EMA) of the loss normalizer. The loss normalizer normalizes the loss according to the number of positive samples when using FocalLoss or GHM without sampling. This is found to stabilize the training and improve performance by Detectron2. By default, it is set as 0 for other sample-based methods or the vanilla RetinaNet.

The code changes in the GIT DIFF show that the method "inRange" in the "DateUtil" class has been modified. The original code was replaced with a new code block that first checks if either the "startDate" or "endDate" is null. If either is null, the function immediately returns false. If both dates are not null, the function continues to calculate the start and end dates by subtracting and adding a second respectively, similar to the original code. However, the variables have been renamed from "startDate" and "endDate" to "before" and "after" respectively. The function then checks if the current date is between these two dates and returns the result. This change adds a null check for the input dates and improves the readability of the code by renaming the variables.
